titleStmt.title: Variants of the feminine ending (final -a) in the environment of non-emphatic and non-back consonants.

sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for Final -a (feminine ending) - In the environment of non-emphatic and non-back consonants:Values: -a, -ä, -e, -i. We consider as emphatic: ṣ - ṭ - ḍ - ḏ̣ - ẓ - ṛ (r after non i) q - g - ġ - x - ḥ - ʕ - h - ʔ.

revisionDesc.change: updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

Pausal form is -ai (Fleisch 1974:222).

"There were a very small number of exceptions in which final short imaala was exhibited, namely ǧamīle (when used as a girl's name HR, AG, senne (year), MW, ED, HR, AI, and also maʕze (goat). Variants of these three items when final raising was not exhibited are also found in the data though. Thus, these are very minor exceptions: essentially the Lebanese nomadic dialects do not exhibit final short imaala." (Pickett 2005:227)

"There were a very small number of exceptions in which final short imaala was exhibited, namely ǧamīle (when used as a girl's name HR, AG, senne (year), MW, ED, HR, AI, and also maʕze (goat). Variants of these three items when final raising was not exhibited are also found in the data though. Thus, these are very minor exceptions: essentially the Lebanese nomadic dialects do not exhibit final short imaala." (Pickett 2005:227)

"There were a very small number of exceptions in which final short imaala was exhibited, namely ǧamīle (when used as a girl's name HR, AG, senne (year), MW, ED, HR, AI, and also maʕze (goat). Variants of these three items when final raising was not exhibited are also found in the data though. Thus, these are very minor exceptions: essentially the Lebanese nomadic dialects do not exhibit final short imaala." (Pickett 2005:227)

"There were a very small number of exceptions in which final short imaala was exhibited, namely ǧamīle (when used as a girl's name HR, AG, senne (year), MW, ED, HR, AI, and also maʕze (goat). Variants of these three items when final raising was not exhibited are also found in the data though. Thus, these are very minor exceptions: essentially the Lebanese nomadic dialects do not exhibit final short imaala." (Pickett 2005:227)

"There were a very small number of exceptions in which final short imaala was exhibited, namely ǧamīle (when used as a girl's name HR, AG, senne (year), MW, ED, HR, AI, and also maʕze (goat). Variants of these three items when final raising was not exhibited are also found in the data though. Thus, these are very minor exceptions: essentially the Lebanese nomadic dialects do not exhibit final short imaala." (Pickett 2005:227)

"There were a very small number of exceptions in which final short imaala was exhibited, namely ǧamīle (when used as a girl's name HR, AG, senne (year), MW, ED, HR, AI, and also maʕze (goat). Variants of these three items when final raising was not exhibited are also found in the data though. Thus, these are very minor exceptions: essentially the Lebanese nomadic dialects do not exhibit final short imaala." (Pickett 2005:227).
This applies to non emphatic environments and also when preceded by ḥ and h, as both consonants do not seem to inhibit raising (Younes 2014:36).
Raising to ä only happens when the feminine ending is preceded by the adjectival ending /y/. Therefore we could consider /ä/ as an alophone of /a/ when preceded by /y/ (Younes 2014:357).
Less frequent
Feminine ending pronounced "et" before article (Carbou 1913:34)
only created for the gahawa
only created for the gahawa
No information about potential vowel harmony
Feminine ending depends on precedent vowel and will be "e" after e or i (Zeltner/Tourneux 1986:38)
Feminine ending depends on precedent vowel and will be "e" after e or i (Zeltner/Tourneux 1986:38)

Holes (2007) claims that the Baḥārna do not raise the ending to the same degree as the ʕArab

cit.quote: she camel which has recently gave birth

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Deduced from examples
When the preceding vowel is fronted, rural (pastoral and sedentary) speakers always raise the feminine ending , whereas urban-pastoral speakers mix between -e and -a
When the preceding vowel is fronted, urban speakers never raise the feminine ending , whereas urban-pastoral speakers mix between -e and -a
Prochazka (1988:19) does not explicitly say that this dialect does not have the ʔimāla, however, it is not mentioned with the dialects that have the ʔimāla

Deduced from examples
The raising of the fem. ending is not consistent, perhaps because of dialect contact (see Arnold 1998:208).
Also non-adjacent emphatic consonants may prevent raising, e.g. ḥuṛma "woman"
Fem.ending remains -a in CaCCa and CaCaCa patterns.
In most words, the fem. ending remains -a, e.g., nʕaǧa 'ewe'.
Fem.ending remains -a in CaCCa and CaCaCa patterns.
Not only conditioned by consonants, but also on vowels. More often in the vicinity of /i/, e.g. kūfiyye "type of headdress" (p.141).
Deduced from examples.
Mostly attested for informants from the inland (as opposed to informants from the coast).
Mostly atteted for informants from the coast (as opposed to informants from the inland).
